topics: Armoured cable (BX, Type AC, ACL, ACWU, TECK)
chapters.content:
Basic electrical concepts for gas-fired equipment installations require understanding of voltage levels, wiring types, protection devices, and code requirements.

Low-Voltage Control Circuits:

The CE Code defines low-voltage circuits as operating from 31V to 1000V AC inclusive. Motor-control circuits may operate at 600V, requiring conductors rated accordingly.

Extra-Low-Voltage Circuits:

Extra-low-voltage circuits operate at 30V or less. Residential thermostat, gas valve, and zone valve control circuits fall into this category. These circuits generally use cable No. 16 AWG or smaller.

Data Cabling:

Modern gas equipment often equipped with network interface devices for LAN connection. Three basic cable types:

1. Twisted pair (most common for short/medium connections)
2. Coaxial
3. Fiber-optic

Unshielded twisted-pair (UTP): Most common in computer networking. Twisting of conductor pairs provides shielding from electromagnetic interference.

Shielded twisted-pair (STP) and screened twisted-pair: Additional shielding from high-frequency signals using foil or braided metal fiber.

Conductor Colour Codes:

White: Only for insulated neutral conductors or identified conductors
Green: Only for insulated grounding or bonding conductors
Red, black, and blue: Typically identifies live (ungrounded) conductors

Non-Metallic Sheathed Cable (NMSC/NMD):

Most commonly used for branch circuit wiring. Usually has PVC or polyethylene plastic insulation serving as outer covering.

Cautions:
- Can burn and transmit fire when ignited
- Burning emits highly toxic gases with dense smoke
- Acidic gas emissions may corrode metals

Armoured Cable (BX):

Flexible outer metal sheath protects insulated conductors. CE Code Rules 12-600 to 12-618 cover installation requirements.

Types:
- Type AC: Dry locations only
- Type ACL: Moisture resistance required (additional lead covering)
- Type ACWU: Wet locations and underground (thermoplastic outer covering)
- TECK: Exposed wiring and adverse service conditions (voltage ratings: 600V, 1kV, or 5kV)

Aluminum-Sheathed Cable (ASC):

Seamless aluminum protective sheath with smooth or corrugated finish. Corrugated type called RA90 (trade name: Corflex). PVC outer covering allows use in adverse conditions. Common in industrial applications (600V to 5000V).

CE Code Table D1 specifies ASC voltage ratings. Rules 12-700 to 12-718 cover installation requirements.

Mineral-Insulated Cable (MI):

Magnesium oxide filler between uninsulated internal conductors and outer metallic sheath (usually copper tubing). Fire-resistant construction. Often called Pyrotenax.

Applications: Where conductors may be exposed to mechanical damage, moisture, or high temperatures.

Requirements: Special termination kits for uninsulated conductors
Ratings: Standard MI up to 600V, LWMI (lightweight) up to 300V

Flexible Cord and Cable:

Not allowed for permanent wiring installations. Used to connect appliances and equipment with attachment plugs.

Types:

Heater cord: Portable electric heating units, 2-4 conductors, high-temperature jacket, 300V max, No. 18 to No. 14 AWG

General-service cord (cab tire): Portable appliances subject to hard usage
- SJ: 300V rated
- S: 600V rated
- SJOW: 300V outdoor use
- SOW: 600V outdoor use
- Available 2-4 conductors, No. 18 to No. 10 AWG

Power-supply cables: Similar to general-service cord, higher currents, up to 600V, 2-4 conductors, No. 8 to No. 2 AWG

Electrical Service:

Electrical service supplied to a building is measured in volts (voltage).

Electric meter records kilowatt-hours (kWh) of energy consumption.

Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter (GFCI):

Protects users from shock hazards in damp conditions. Detects ground faults and interrupts power.

Reset: Push button on receptacle (not at panel, not by replacing fuse, not by moving handle).

Bonding:

Definition: Permanently joining all non-current-carrying metal parts to ensure electrical continuity.

Minimum conductor size for bonding gas piping systems to building's electrical grounding: No. 6 AWG

Overcurrent Protection:

Most common device in residential applications: Circuit breakers (not fuses, not GFCI, not transformers)

Maximum ampacity values for overcurrent protection devices specified in: CSA C22.1 (CE Code)

Causes of overcurrent:
1. Short circuit (most likely)
2. Motor startup (normal, brief overcurrent)

Electrical overload: Does NOT occur very quickly (develops gradually as heat builds up)

Advantage of circuit breakers over fuses: Can be easily reset (not replaced, not lower failure rate, cannot be bypassed)

Wire Conductors:

Wire is the most common form of electrical conductor.

Stranded wire has nearly the same current-carrying capacity as solid wire of the same gauge.

AWG sizing: Lower number = larger diameter = higher ampacity
- No. 10 AWG has GREATER ampacity than No. 14 AWG

Installation with Steel Studs:

For installations with steel studs and joists as framing members: Use armoured cable (BX)
- Not NMSC, not NMD, not SOW (flexible cord)

Interrupting Capacity:

Definition: The maximum supply amperage that the breaker is rated for
- Not the protected circuit amperage
- Not when breaker begins to open
- Not unbalanced current amount

Low-Voltage AC Circuit Operation:

Low-voltage AC circuits operate at: 31V to 1000V
- Not 1000 mV or less (that's 1V)
- Not 1V to 30V (that's extra-low)
- Not 30V to 250V (incorrect range)

Adverse Service Conditions:

Type of armoured cable for adverse service conditions: TECK (not AC, not ACL, not ACWU)

chapters.content:
Understanding electrical drawings is essential for gas technicians to interpret equipment wiring, troubleshoot problems, and install systems correctly.

Types of Electrical Drawings:

Four main forms:
1. Pictorial diagrams (component layout)
2. Connection or wiring diagrams
3. Ladder or schematic diagrams
4. Block diagrams

Pictorial Diagrams:

Often used in instruction manuals and installation guides. Generally three-dimensional.

Characteristics:
- Components drawn as they appear in real life
- Components located relative to actual position
- Wires and items identified by color, value, or rating
- Helpful for recognizing and locating components
- Useful for field wiring
- May be difficult to understand circuit operation

Connection (Wiring) Diagrams:

Similar to pictorial but less detailed.

Characteristics:
- Components represented by symbols (not as they appear)
- Components located relative to actual position
- Show how wires are actually connected to component terminals
- Best used as "map" of electrical circuit
- Excellent for tracing wires when troubleshooting
- Shows wiring identification and ratings

Purpose: Show where components are physically located and how wires connect.

Ladder and Schematic Diagrams:

Purpose: Show how circuits work and the function of components.

Characteristics:
- Components represented by standard electrical symbols
- Components labeled (name, type, value, part number)
- Components NOT shown in actual location
- Components connected by single lines showing relationships
- All components shown in de-energized state
- Show logical sequence of events

Ladder Diagram Features:
- Two vertical "rails" labeled L1 (hot) and N (neutral)
- Represents 120V AC potential between rails
- Separate circuits shown as "rungs" of ladder
- Each rung has source voltage from left, switches, and load
- Easier to read right to left (identify loads first, then controls)
- Shows clear voltage separation above/below transformer

Application: Best for understanding circuit operation, determining sequence of operation.

Block Diagrams:

Type of flow chart showing relationship between components or groups of components.

Characteristics:
- Components drawn as labeled blocks
- Components NOT shown in actual location
- Connected by single lines showing relationships
- Do NOT show return path for circuits
- Show component name, type, value, part number

"At Rest" State:

All wiring diagrams drawn in "at rest" (de-energized) state:
- Main disconnect device in open position
- Heating/cooling devices not operating or at rest
- No devices energized or operating
- All devices in normal positions with power off

Normal Switch Positions:

Normally Open (NO): Drawn in open position, will not change until switched (manually, remotely, or automatically)

Normally Closed (NC): Drawn in closed position, will not change until switched

Remote switching: Indirectly by relay
Automatic switching: Mechanical device responding to environmental changes

Example: Temperature-Activated Switch (T.A.S.) that is normally open and makes/closes on temperature drop.

Control Device Call-Up:

Control devices include:
- Temperature controls
- Pressure controls
- Humidity controls
- Flow controls
- Level controls

On wiring diagrams:
- Represented by symbols
- Identified by position, type, and action

Correct identification: "Normally open temperature control that breaks/opens on temperature rise and closes on temperature drop" (not just "heating thermostat")

Controls open or close in response to increase (rise) or decrease (fall) in:
- Temperature
- Pressure
- Humidity
- Fluid flow

Factory Wiring:

Done at manufacture time. Permanent wiring including printed circuits, wiring harness assemblies, individual cables and conductors.

Designation on diagrams: Solid lines

Field Wiring:

Done by gas technician at installation time. Includes cabling for power supply connection and modifications for specific applications.

Designation on diagrams: Broken lines (dashed lines)

Reading Electrical Drawings:

Each drawing type has specific advantages:

Pictorial: Recognizing and locating components, wiring color coding
Connection/Wiring: Finding exactly how and where wires connect, tracing wires
Schematic/Ladder: Understanding circuit operation, determining sequence, identifying control relationships
Block: Understanding system overview and component relationships

Limitations:

Pictorial and wiring diagrams do NOT show:
- How switches are activated
- Whether by time, temperature, pressure, or manual operation
- Order of sequence (unless familiar with components)

Gas technicians should have thorough understanding of electrical symbols to interpret all diagram types effectively.

chapters.content:
Proper use of electrical measuring instruments is essential for troubleshooting gas-fired equipment. The digital multimeter (DMM) is the primary tool for electrical measurements.

Digital Multimeter (DMM):

A multimeter incorporates all of the following basic electrical meters:
- Voltmeter
- Ammeter
- Ohmmeter

Functions enable measurement of voltage, current, resistance, and often capacitance, frequency, and continuity.

Clamp-On Ammeter:

Can measure current in a conductor WITHOUT being inserted into circuit. Useful for checking loads like electric motors without interrupting operation.

Procedure:
1. Open ammeter jaws by squeezing handle
2. Close jaws over conductor
3. Ensure ONLY ONE conductor enclosed (if both live and neutral enclosed, meter reads zero)
4. Ensure jaws completely closed (dirty/obstructed jaws = inaccurate reading)
5. Read current on ammeter display

Note: In-line ammeter is connected in series with circuit, requires breaking circuit.

Ammeter Connection:

An ammeter is connected in SERIES with circuit under test (not parallel).

Measuring Resistance:

Ohmmeter used to measure resistance.

Connection: Across unpowered device or circuit

Important: Ohmmeter should NEVER be connected to live circuit - will damage meter and create safety hazard

Best practice: Isolate devices being tested from circuit

Continuity Check:

A continuity check is a measurement of resistance. Low resistance indicates continuity (continuous path). High resistance or "OL" (overload/open circuit) indicates no continuity.

When probes touched together in resistance test: Meter should read 0 (zero ohms)

DMM Symbols:

Common symbols:
- AC: Alternating current (wavy line ~)
- DC: Direct current (solid/dashed lines)
- Ω: Ohms (resistance)
- V: Volts
- A: Amperes
- Hz: Hertz (frequency)
- μF: Microfarad (capacitance)
- Continuity: Speaker/sound wave symbol
- +/- : Positive/negative polarity
- Low battery indicator
- OL: Overload/open circuit

Unit Conversions:

Voltage conversions:
- 250 mV = 0.25 V (divide mV by 1000)
- 1000 mV = 1 V

Resistance conversions:
- 2.125 kΩ = 2125 Ω (multiply kΩ by 1000)
- 1 kΩ = 1000 Ω

Testing Furnace Fan Circuit:

DMM should be set at voltage AC function when testing furnace fan circuit.

Step 1 - Check appliance disconnect switch:
- Verify disconnect wired into L1 (hot line)
- Verify disconnect shuts off power supply

Step 2 - Take readings for circuit voltages:
- L1 to ground with disconnect closed: Should read 120V
- N to ground with disconnect closed: Should read 0V

Step 3 - Open disconnect and retake readings:
- Verify L1 to ground: 0V
- Verify N to ground: 0V
- Confirms disconnect on L1 and shuts off power

Step 4 - Retake reading with disconnect closed:
- Between L1 and N: Should read 120V (source voltage)

Step 5 - Take readings across fan switch:
- Open fan switch: Should read 120V
- Closed fan switch: Should read 0V

Step 6 - Take readings across motor terminals:
- Fan switch open: Should read 0V
- Fan switch closed (motor energized): Should read 120V

Testing Transformer Circuit:

120V AC line voltage circuit to high limit and step-down transformer:

Meter A (across L1 and N): Should read 120V (source voltage)

Meter B (across high limit):
- Closed high limit: Should read 0V
- Open high limit: Should read 120V

Meter C (secondary side of transformer): Should read 24V (or slightly higher with no load, 26-27V)

Testing 24V Control Circuit:

Consists of 24V AC power supply, gas valve, and thermostat:

Meter A (across thermopile terminals):
- Should read 24V with load
- 26-27V with no load on transformer
- Returns to 24V when control circuit energized

Meter B (across thermostat terminals):
- Thermostat open (no call for heat): Should read 24V
- Thermostat closed (call for heat): Should read 0V

Meter C (across gas valve coil):
- Thermostat open: Should read 0V
- Thermostat closed: Should read 24V

Switch State Diagnosis:

If you measure voltage across a switch in energized circuit: Switch is OPEN

If you measure correct voltage across a load but load does not work: The load has failed

Series Circuit Voltage:

If one component in series circuit is open: Voltage drop across open component will equal source voltage

Location B Reading:

On typical furnace diagram with 120V supply to 24V transformer:
- Location B (secondary of transformer with no load): Would read approximately 24V AC (or slightly higher 26-27V with no load)

Ampere vs Current:

Ampere is also known as: Current (not power, not resistance, not electromotive force)

Safety Requirements:

Testing circuits may require working with live voltage. Use extreme caution.

Follow CSA Z462 as minimum requirement for live work:
- Only if trained
- Only if authorized by employer
- Using all recommended personal protective equipment
- Consider arc flash hazards

chapters.content:
Understanding electrical components and devices is essential for proper installation and maintenance of gas-fired equipment.

Heavy-Duty Contactors:

Solenoid/armature operators for switching heavy-duty electrical contacts. Used to control large currents and high voltages for industrial equipment.

Components:
- Solenoid coil (typically 110V or 24V control circuit)
- Armature with insulators
- Conductive crossbars
- Multiple sets of contacts

Operation: Switch in coil circuit simultaneously activates high-voltage circuit (e.g., 208V three-phase to motor).

Difference from relay: Contacts rated for large currents (heavy duty), can have multiple contact sets, magnetically operated

Three-Phase Motor Starters:

Magnetic motor starters required for three-phase motors to provide:
- Overload sensing circuit
- Protection from single-phase conditions
- Protection from excessive current draw
- Thermal overload protection

Components:
- Contactor with multiple contacts (one per phase)
- Thermal overload relays
- START/STOP control buttons
- Holding contacts

Operation: START button energizes coil, closes all phase contacts simultaneously. Thermal overload trips if motor overheats or draws excessive current.

Residential Distribution Panel:

Hot wires in service conductors: Two (in residential single-phase 120/240V service)

Branch circuits start: At the distribution panel (not wall switch, not pole transformer, not appliance transformer)

Continuous ground: Connects at each receptacle, each appliance, and each junction box

Transformers:

Rated by: The amount of power the secondary windings can handle
- Not by voltage supply alone
- Not by connected circuit breaker
- Not by ampacity of supply conductors

Rating expressed in VA (volt-amperes) or kVA (kilovolt-amperes)

Electrical Connections:

All electrical connections should be made: In outlet or junction boxes
- Not in conduit
- Not in appliance (unless manufacturer-provided connection)
- Not in distribution panel (except main connections)

Bonding Conductors:

Bonding conductors must NOT be soldered. Use mechanical connections (crimps, bolts, clamps).

Reason: Solder can melt in fault conditions, compromising ground.

Switches:

Location: Always located in hot leg of circuit (never in neutral)

Position to conduct current: Closed position (not open)

Operation: Manually or by pressure, temperature, fluid flow (all of the above)

Toggle Motor Starters:

Despite similarity to light switch contacts, toggle motor starter contacts are: HP-rated (horsepower-rated)
- Not just current-rated
- Not located on neutral leg
- Not solder-only connections

This rating accounts for high inrush currents and sustained motor loads.

Relays:

Operate according to: Solenoid principle (electromagnet principle)
- Not microwave principle
- Not Bernoulli's principle
- Not plasma principles

Control relays: NOT best suited for controlling single-phase pumps of any size (limited to smaller loads)

For larger single-phase motors: Use motor starters or contactors

Boxes:

Device Boxes:

Support switches and other devices. Two types:
1. Gangable type (one side removable to add boxes)
2. Non-gangable type

CE Code requirements:
- Gas appliances connected to electrical circuit must have disconnect switch
- Switch mounted near appliance in approved box
- Used to shut off power during emergencies or servicing
- Must be accessible without passing close to furnace
- Must be clearly marked

Junction Boxes:

Often mounted directly on gas appliance. Connections between branch circuit and appliance control system made in junction box.

Purpose:
- Meet CE Code requirements
- Prevent short circuits
- Prevent electric shock hazards

Octagon boxes: Support lighting fixtures or junction points, can be switch/outlet boxes with special covers

Square boxes:
- 4 in wide (most common) - can be fitted for switches, receptacles, pilot lights
- 4 11/16 in square - generally for range or dryer receptacles

Gangable Box:

Definition: Multiple boxes that can be joined together (not switch-only, not receptacle-only, not octagonal-type)

Sockets and Plugs:

Specialty types can be locking or non-locking.

Non-locking: Inserted straight, relies on contact friction, pulled straight out

Locking: Inserted straight, rotated clockwise to lock, must be rotated counterclockwise to withdraw

Each assembly has different configurations and voltage/current ratings based on application.

Crimp-On Connectors:

Crimp-on connectors are NOT convenient without special tools. They require crimping tools for proper installation.

Conduit and Tubing:

Used to contain and protect electrical conductors. Classified by wall thickness, mechanical stiffness, and material.

Types:
- RMC (Rigid Metal Conduit): Made to same dimensions as standard pipe
- EMT (Electrical Metallic Tubing): Thin-walled metal tubing
- Rigid PVC conduit: Rigid non-metallic
- FMC (Flexible Metallic Conduit): Easily bent without tools
- LFMC (Liquid-tight Flexible Metallic Conduit): For wet locations

CE Code covers installation requirements depending on equipment type, location, or hazard.

chapters.content:
Millivoltage control systems use thermocouples and thermopiles to generate electrical power from pilot flame heat, eliminating need for external power source.

Thermocouples:

Point where two dissimilar metals are joined: Hot junction

Used with: Standing pilot (not direct pilot, not interrupted pilot, not intermittent pilot)

Thermocouple Operation:

When heated, thermocouple powers: Safety coil (not fan, not thermostat, not main gas valve directly)

Hot junction heating: First 0.375 to 0.5 in of thermocouple should be heated by pilot flame (not full length, not 1/2 in from top, not bottom/base 1/2 in)

Temperature difference between hot and cold junctions: Minimum of 400°F (204°C) required for proper operation

Thermocouple Testing:

Open-Circuit Test:

Performed: WITHOUT load connected (not under load)
Expected reading: 30 mV minimum
Procedure: Heat thermocouple, disconnect from valve, measure voltage
Shows: Millivolt output not under load, unheated thermocouple capability

Closed-Circuit Test:

Shows: Millivolt maintained under load
Replacement criteria: If cannot produce closed-circuit reading of more than 8 mV
Procedure: Heat thermocouple while connected to safety valve coil
Tests: Ability to maintain voltage under load conditions

Important: An external power source is NOT required for control circuit operating on thermopile millivoltage (self-powered system)

Thermopiles:

Construction: Contains approximately 10 to 30 thermocouples

Connection: Multiple thermocouples electrically connected in series (not parallel)

Output: Produces direct current (DC), not AC, not three-phase, not magnetic

Ratings: 250 mV, 500 mV, or 750 mV systems

750 mV Usage: When two millivolt circuits are powered (not when AC power required, not three-phase, not circulating fan - that requires AC power)

Testing 750 mV Circuit: Essentially same as testing 500 mV circuit, except for testing pilotstat (safety coil)

Pilot Flame Characteristics:

Causes of very small blue pilot flame:
- Low gas pressure
- Clogged pilot filter
- Restricted pilot orifice
- All of the above

Proper flame ensures adequate thermocouple/thermopile heating.

Pilotstat Coil Testing:

Dropout reading: Coil should drop out at reading between 5 and 2 mV (not 2-1, not 20-15, not 30-15)

Dropout timing: Should drop out within 90 seconds of extinguished flame (not after 3 min, not after 90 sec, not within 3 sec)

Note: The maximum time allowed for thermocouple to cool down and stop gas flow after pilot outage is 90 seconds

Test procedure:
1. With thermostat calling for heat, depress manual reset
2. Light pilot, wait for 170 mV reading
3. Release manual reset button
4. If valve doesn't hold in, replace coil
5. If holds in, blow out pilot and watch meter
6. If coil drops out over 140 mV, replace coil

Testing 500 mV Control Systems:

Five test positions measure different voltage drops:

Position 1: Thermopile full output (254 mV typical)
Position 2: Valve coil voltage (140 mV typical, minimum 60 mV to open, safety margin to 150 mV)
Position 3: Thermostat and wire total loss (112 mV typical, max 50 mV without anticipator, 110 mV with anticipator)
Position 4: Thermostat loss (80 mV typical, max 8 mV without anticipator, 100 mV with anticipator)
Position 5: Limit and wire loss (2 mV typical, should be close to zero)

Wire loss calculation: Position 3 - Position 4 = Wire loss
If over 60 mV, check for poor splices

Verification: Position 2 + Position 3 + Position 5 should equal Position 1 (within 15 mV)

Troubleshooting Example 1:

Readings: 1=269 mV, 2=77 mV, 3=190 mV, 4=30 mV, 5=2 mV
Problem: Wire loss = 190 - 30 = 160 mV (too high)
Solution: Bad wiring contacts or poor splice, clean terminals and solder splice

Troubleshooting Example 2 (Circuit diagram with 5 positions):

Reading 1=500 mV, 2=500 mV, 3=0 mV, 4=0 mV, 5=0 mV
Problem: Broken coil in gas valve
Analysis: Full voltage at position 1 and 2, but zero across thermostat circuit indicates valve coil open circuit

Reading 1=500 mV, 2=0 mV, 3=500 mV, 4=0 mV, 5=0 mV
Problem: Faulty thermostat wiring
Analysis: Voltage present across thermostat/wire position but not reaching valve indicates wiring issue

750 mV Systems:

Two circuits powered:
1. Safety circuit: Pilotstat coil only
2. Control circuit: Thermostat, limit switch, gas valve coil

Wired in parallel so safety circuit continuously energized.

Open-circuit voltage: 750 mV
With pilotstat connected: Drops to approximately 550 mV at position 1
With both circuits closed: Drops to 185 mV (no anticipator) or 240 mV (with anticipator)

Control circuit test values same as 500 mV systems.

Millivolt Thermostats:

Voltage rating of dedicated millivolt thermostat: 0 to 1.5 V DC
- Not 120 V AC
- Not 20 to 30 V AC
- Not 250 to 750 V DC

Important: Using 24V thermostat on millivolt system causes excessive resistance and voltage loss. Using millivolt thermostat on 24V AC system damages thermostat.

Most digital thermostats rated for both 24V AC or millivolt systems (run on backup batteries when wired for millivolt).

Total System Resistance:

Total electrical resistance in control system includes: Heat anticipator in thermostat (statement is TRUE)

Self-Powered System Components:

- Pilot burner
- Thermopile or pilot generator
- Diaphragm gas valve (includes safety shut-off)
- Limit switch
- Millivolt thermostat (may include heat anticipator)
- Wire runs connecting devices

Wiring Requirements:

Manufacturer recommends maximum lengths (statement is TRUE)

Correct type and gauge critical for staying within system resistance limits.

Maximum wire run lengths (typical, may vary by manufacturer):

Up to 30 ft (9 m): Use No. 18 AWG minimum
Up to 50 ft (15 m): Use No. 16 AWG minimum
Up to 80 ft (24 m): Use No. 14 AWG minimum

Recommended maximum length using typical LVT No. 18 AWG on millivolt system: 30 ft (9 m)
- Not 5 ft
- Not 50 ft (requires No. 16 AWG)
- Not 80 ft (requires No. 14 AWG)

Guidelines for two-wire control system cables. Some manufacturer recommendations may differ and must be followed.

chapters.content:
AC electric motors are critical components in gas-fired equipment, driving fans, blowers, and pumps. Understanding motor types, protection devices, and control systems is essential.

Motor Nameplate Information:

Where found: On motor nameplate (not frame, not housing, not armature)

Information includes:
- Rated horsepower (HP)
- Speed (RPM)
- Full load amperage (FLA)
- Date code
- Voltage rating
- Service factor
- Frame size

Motor Main Parts:

Two main parts: Stator and rotor (not capacitor, not centrifugal switch - these are accessories)

Stator: Stationary part with coil windings creating rotating magnetic field
Rotor: Rotating part inside stator, turns due to magnetic field interaction

Wound Rotor vs Squirrel Cage:

Difference: Wound rotor motor has insulated windings (with slip rings and brushes for external resistance connection)

Squirrel cage induction motor: Does NOT have insulated windings (has cast aluminum or copper bars short-circuited by end rings), no slip rings or brushes

Squirrel cage characteristics:
- Simpler construction
- Lower maintenance
- No brushes to wear
- Most common type

Three-Phase Induction Motors:

Stator phase coils can be connected: Delta or Wye (not AC/DC, not in phase/out of phase, not synchronized/asynchronized)

Delta: Coils connected in triangle
Wye: Coils connected in Y-shape with common center point

Synchronous Motors:

Biggest design difference from induction motor: DC electromagnetic rotor (not squirrel cage rotor, not start capacitor, not external start resistor)

Synchronous motor rotor has DC electromagnets creating constant magnetic poles. Rotates in exact synchronization with rotating magnetic field (no slip).

Starting Relays:

Three types in common use:

1. Current Relay:

Has normally open contacts that close with high inrush current and open once motor reaches running speed.

Operation:
- Coil in series with run winding
- Weight or spring holds start contacts open when idle
- High starting current magnetizes coil, closes start contacts
- As motor accelerates, current decreases, relay opens start contacts
- Used on small capacitor-start induction-run motors

2. Potential Relay:

Has normally closed set of start winding contacts opened by relay coil after motor starts.

Operation:
- Contacts held closed by gravity or spring
- Coil connected across start winding
- As motor accelerates, voltage across start winding increases (back EMF)
- Higher voltage energizes coil, opens normally closed contacts
- No arcing when circuit initially closes (big advantage)
- Used with larger capacitor-start motors

3. Solid-State Relay:

Uses transistors, diodes, and triacs to break start windings circuit at correct time.

Operation:
- Senses voltage changes in motor as it starts
- Opens start circuit at correct speed
- Not as sensitive to motor size
- Same relay can work for motors 1/12 to 1/3 HP

Capacitors:

Testing and Replacement:

When removing or replacing capacitor: Always short out terminals to drain any stored charge (safety precaution)

Replacement capacitor: Should be same voltage and capacity as old capacitor. If different, should be 5-10% over capacity rather than under.

Most common cause of failure: Ground or open-circuit condition

Testing: Most multimeters check for ground or open-circuit conditions

Overload Protection Devices:

Purpose: To protect motor from overheating

Two fundamental principles:

1. Temperature-Sensing Device (Motor Thermostat):

Directly senses motor-winding temperature. Does NOT carry current (would give false reading if it did). Usually automatic reset type.

Reset time: 20 min to 1 hour (small motor), several hours (large motor). Prolonged if multiple trips in succession or motor already hot.

Internal type: Better protection, faster response
External type: Cannot sense changes as quickly

2. Current-Sensing Device (Temperature Disc, Klixon Disc):

Current flows through bimetal disc, heats it. Predetermined current causes disc to warp, opens contacts. After cooling, automatically resets.

Type: Replica protection

Mounting: Inside small motor housings or externally

Replacement: Must use exact replacement for proper protection. Place where manufacturer designated.

External Overload Protection:

Provided by starter with overload devices calibrated to motor operating conditions. Can be manual or automatic.

Thermal overload: Trips starter and disengages circuit under excessive conditions.

Three-phase motors require overload sensing for:
- Single-phase conditions (phase loss)
- Excessive current draw from high load demands

Motor Insulation:

Primary cause of failure: Motor overheating

Functions:
1. Separate electrical components from each other and structural parts
2. Protect from contaminants and destructive forces

Heat causes deterioration, resulting in breakdown, short circuits, and motor failure.

Ambient Temperature:

Standard ambient temperature for insulation rating: 40°C (104°F)

Motor begins to overheat when air or contacting medium exceeds 40°C.

Bearings:

Types:
- Sleeve bushing (requires periodic lubrication through grease fittings)
- Ball bearing (sealed, self-lubricating)
- Roller bearing (sealed, self-lubricating)

Determining lubrication needs: By presence of grease fittings (not rating plate, specifications, or power supply)

When repaired: May replace with sealed-for-life bearings, remove grease fittings, plug holes

Motor Direction of Rotation:

Viewed from: Drive end of motor (not top, not either end, not non-drive end)

Speed Control:

Direct Drive Motors:

PSC direct drive fan motor: Directly linked to fan wheel

Multispeed PSC motor: Identified by number of wires at electrical connections

Determine speed tap wires: By wiring schematic color codes (not trial and error, not furnace specs, not control board schematic)

Speed control: More resistance = slower speed, less resistance = higher speed

Electronically Commutated Motor (ECM):

Best description: DC, three-phase motor with permanent magnet rotor (not split-phase induction, not shaded-pole induction, not PSC)

Construction:
- Two separate components: motor and control section
- Microprocessor calibrated at factory
- Motor has permanent magnet rotor (no windings in rotor)
- Control section includes microprocessor

Operation:
- Adapts speed to match system conditions
- Maintains set CFM (like cruise control)
- Monitors relationship between speed, torque, and airflow
- As static pressure increases (dirty filter), increases RPM to maintain CFM
- Efficiency range: 60-80% among all speeds
- PSC motor: 10% efficiency at low speeds, 50% at high speeds

Communication: 16-pin harness from control board indicating desired CFM for operating state

Motion Control Positioning Motors:

Types commonly referred to as:
- Actuating motors
- Motor operators
- Modulating motors
- Electronic actuators

Methods:
1. Powered fully open or closed
2. Floating action
3. Servo motors
4. Stepper motors

Floating Action:

Receives powered voltage control signal to move valve. Controller provides power to drive motor open or closed, or no power to remain in position. Simple, cost-effective. Uses actuator timing to position valve.

Stepper Motors:

Open-loop positioning system converting digital pulses into mechanical shaft rotations. Brushless DC motor moving in increments (steps) rather than smooth rotation.

Operation:
- Internal rotor: magnetic wheel with salient poles
- External magnets switched electronically
- Coils switched on/off in specific sequence
- Motor shaft turns one step at a time
- Can operate clockwise or counterclockwise
- Holds position until different coils energized
- Steps per revolution: 4 to 500 (90° to 0.75° per step)

Application: Gas valves with stepper motor modulate servo regulator, fully modulating manifold pressure and firing rate.

Servo Motors:

Part of closed-loop system. Includes positioning circuit accepting analogue control signal (0-10V or 4-20mA).

Features:
- Position sensor (potentiometer) feeds actual position back to positioning circuit
- Can position along stroke in proportion to control signal
- Used where high degree of accuracy and acceleration required

Actuator interprets control signal as valve position between limit switches.

CSA Unit 12 Basic Electricity
Chapter 1
Power Supply for Gas 
Appliances
Most gas appliances are designed with some electrical components to 
aid in their operation. It is important for gas technicians and fitters to 
understand how power is supplied and accessed, as well as the various 
methods and devices used to ensure that electricity is distributed safely.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Electrical Service Overview
Purpose
Understanding electrical components in gas appliances and how power is safely 
distributed
Objectives
Describe electrical services, ground fault circuit interrupters, electrical bonding to 
gas piping, single and three-phase power, types and ratings of fuses and breakers, 
and types and gauges of wire
Key Terminology
Term
Definition
Ampacity
The amount of current a conductor is 
rated to safely handle
Bonding
Permanent joining of all non-current-
carrying metal parts to ensure electrical 
continuity and establish a low-
impedance path
Conductor
A material that allows electrical current 
to flow through it with relative ease
Electrolysis
Chemical breakdown of two metals in 
contact reacting with one another
Ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI)
A specially designed receptacle or 
distribution panel circuit breaker used to 
protect users from electric shock
More Key Terminology
Term
Definition
Grounding
Connection of all exposed non-current-
carrying metal parts to the earth that 
provides a direct path for unwanted 
current
Non-metallic-sheathed cable (dry) - 
NMD
For exposed wiring in dry or damp 
locations and for concealed wiring in dry 
or damp locations
Non-metallic-sheathed cable (wet) - 
NMW
For exposed wiring in dry locations, wet 
locations, and for concealed wiring in dry 
locations
Overcurrent device
Main circuit breaker or a pair of fuses that 
protect the line wires and transfer power 
to the two hot bus bars
Overload
Moderate increase in current beyond the 
rated current value
Electrical Generation and Distribution
Power Generation
Turbines driven by wind, water, steam, or gas
Transmission
High voltage lines carry power from sources
Distribution
Lines connect to individual customers
Almost all commercial electrical power on Earth is generated with a turbine, which drives a generator, transforming 
mechanical energy into electrical energy through electromagnetic induction. The electrical grid is an interconnected network 
for delivering electricity from producers to consumers.
Power Distribution Network
Generating Stations
Produce electrical power
Step-Up Transformers
Change voltage to a level suitable for transmission
Transmission Lines
Carry power long distances
Substations
Step down voltage from transmission to distribution level
Service Location
Final step down to required service voltage
Three-Phase Power Applications
Uses
Three-phase power supply is used to power large motors 
and other heavy loads. A three-phase system is generally 
more economical than equivalent single-phase or two-
phase systems at the same voltage.
Three-phase, three- and four-wire systems are used for 
industrial and commercial applications.
Four-Wire System Components
•
Three hot line wires
•
A ground wire
•
A neutral may also be included, at times
Four commonly supplied voltages are: 120/208 V, 240/416 
V, 347/600 V, and 600 V.
Three-Phase Wire Color 
Coding
Wire
Colour
Neutral (when present)
White or natural grey
Phase A (phase wire A)
Red
Phase B (phase wire B)
Black
Phase C (phase wire C)
Blue
The neutral wire (the identified circuit conductor) must have the same 
colour throughout the whole length of the circuit it services, for 
conductor sizes up to No. 2 AWG. Identified circuit conductors larger 
than No. 2 AWG must be identified at both ends with white tape, unless 
the conductor is white.
Residential Service 
Requirements
Minimum Requirements
The minimum requirement in most new residential construction is 100-
amp service
Older Homes
Many older homes have 60-amp services
Electric Heating
Homes heated by electricity require a 200-amp service
Service Upgrades
As more appliances are added, the electrical service may need to be 
upgraded to a higher amperage rating
Electrical Distribution System Components
Electric Meter
Records the amount of electrical energy in kilowatt-hours consumed over a certain period
Main Switch
Used to shut off the supply of electricity to the building
Distribution Panel
Contains fuses or circuit breakers that connect the electrical supply to various loads
Fuses/Circuit Breakers
Protect conductors from overloads and short circuits
Wire Conductors
Carry electricity to various circuits throughout the building
Fuses and Circuit Breakers
Sizing
Fuses and circuit breakers are sized according to the wire they protect, and the wire is 
sized according to the load of the individual branch circuits.
Circuit Limitations
120 V branch circuits are limited to a maximum number of receptacles and fixtures to 
avoid overloading. Some 120 V appliances, such as refrigerators and freezers, require 
separate circuits and breakers.
Heating Circuits
Individual heating circuits are limited to a maximum wattage rating and have separate 
fuses or breakers.
High-Load Appliances
Electric ranges, dryers, and hot waters are on separate circuits, protected by high-
amperage fuses or breakers.
Wire Conductors
Branch Circuit Sizing
Individual branch circuits are sized according to the size of 
wire used in the circuit: as more circuits are added, the total 
current increases.
Most residential lighting and receptacle circuits and other 
120 V circuits are supplied by 14-2 AWG (14-gauge, 2-wire, 
plus bond) conductors. Heating circuits, including most hot 
water heaters, generally use 12-2 AWG conductors, while 
ranges and dryers require much heavier gauge conductors.
Appliance Wiring
Wire used in the internal wiring of gas-fired appliances will 
frequently be a lighter (smaller) gauge and is generally of 
the multi-stranded type of design. Appliances are 
manufactured in accordance with a particular standard and 
are certified for use with specific wiring. Any repairs to this 
wiring must conform to the same standard.
External wiring must conform to the electrical code adopted 
in the province where the work is being performed.
Wire Size and Ratings
Wire size
Rating (amperage)
Breaker size (amps)
#14
15 A
15 A
#12
20 A
20 A
#10
30 A
30 A
#8
45 A
40 A
#6
65 A
60 A
#3
105 A
100 A
Always refer to the Canadian Electrical Code, Part I (CE Code) and the manufacturer for the correct application of wire and ratings.
Gas Piping System Hazards
Fire and Shock Hazards
The gas piping system in a building can create fire and 
shock hazards throughout the building if it is not properly 
bonded to ground
Fault Current Path
The piping system can become a path for a fault current 
event from the electrical system
Equipotential Bonding
Bonding of conductive pipes and systems is provided to 
prevent them from carrying a voltage different from the 
electrical system
Metal Gas Tubing
The requirement to provide equipotential bonding to a 
metal gas piping system is not intended to apply to metal 
gas tubing
Benefits of Bonding and Grounding
Shock Protection
Protect persons from electric shock hazards
Short Circuit Path
Provides a path for short circuit current
Property Protection
Protect property from damage caused by short circuits and 
lightning
Circuit Protection
Open fuses and circuit breakers when short circuits occur
Interior gas piping systems are electrically bonded to ground at the electrical panel to prevent possible hazards. Bonding the gas piping 
system to ground prevents arcing (sparking) due to electrical potential difference between the piping and ground, reducing the risk of 
accidental ignition.
Purpose of Fuses and Breakers
Protection Devices
The fuse and the circuit breaker are the two most commonly 
used devices for the protection of electrical systems. The 
purpose of a protective device is to open the electrical 
circuit, stopping current flow, before damage can be done to 
the conductors and equipment connected to the circuit.
Key Differences
The difference between fuses and circuit breakers is that:
•
Fuses are one-time-use only devices and must be 
replaced when they activate and open
•
Circuit breakers can be reset if they trip
All fuses and breakers are sized to protect the circuit 
conductors, not the appliances connected to the circuit. 
Fuses and breakers must not be oversized.
Fuse and Breaker Applications
Time-Delay Fuses
Time-delay fuses should be used to protect inductive type circuits 
(motors) and where intermittent, momentarily high loads will be 
encountered, such as motor and air conditioning circuits.
Code Specifications
The CE Code specifies maximum ampacity values for fuses, breakers, 
and other protective devices.
Manufacturer Details
Each fuse or breaker manufacturer has specific details of the use and 
application of electrical circuit protectors. Electrical safety and 
protective devices are matched to the application to ensure the right 
overcurrent protection.
Replacement Guidelines
When changing a circuit protector, replace it with the same type as 
originally provided by the manufacturer or consult the manufacturer for 
the correct replacement.
Safety Warnings for Circuit 
Protection
Never change a fuse with the power on!
Always disconnect power before replacing fuses to prevent 
electrical shock
Never work live unless you are authorized and 
supervised!
Working on energized circuits requires special training and 
authorization
Understanding Overloads
An overload is a moderate increase in current beyond the rated current 
value and exposes conductors and equipment to more current than their 
design allows.
A circuit becomes overloaded when the equipment connected to it draws 
more current than that for which the circuit is designed or rated. The 
heat produced by an overload often causes electrical insulation 
deterioration and failure. During an overload, t

Benefits of Bonding and Grounding
Shock Protection
Protect persons from electric shock hazards
Short Circuit Path
Provides a path for short circuit current
Property Protection
Protect property from damage caused by short circuits and lightning
Circuit Protection
Open fuses and circuit breakers when short circuits occur
Interior gas piping systems are electrically bonded to ground at the electrical panel to prevent possible hazards. Bonding the gas piping system to ground prevents arcing (sparking) due to electrical potential difference between the piping and ground, reducing the risk of accidental ignition.
Purpose of Fuses and Breakers
Protection Devices
The fuse and the circuit breaker are the two most commonly used devices for the protection of electrical systems. The purpose of a protective device is to open the electrical circuit, stopping current flow, before damage can be done to the conductors and equipment connected to the circuit.
Key Differences
The difference between fuses and circuit breakers is that:
Fuses are one-time-use only devices and must be replaced when they activate and open
Circuit breakers can be reset if they trip
All fuses and breakers are sized to protect the circuit conductors, not the appliances connected to the circuit. Fuses and breakers must not be oversized.
Fuse and Breaker Applications
Time-Delay Fuses
Time-delay fuses should be used to protect inductive type circuits (motors) and where intermittent, momentarily high loads will be encountered, such as motor and air conditioning circuits.
Code Specifications
The CE Code specifies maximum ampacity values for fuses, breakers, and other protective devices.
Manufacturer Details
Each fuse or breaker manufacturer has specific details of the use and application of electrical circuit protectors. Electrical safety and protective devices are matched to the application to ensure the right overcurrent protection.
Replacement Guidelines
When changing a circuit protector, replace it with the same type as originally provided by the manufacturer or consult the manufacturer for the correct replacement.
Safety Warnings for Circuit Protection
Never change a fuse with the power on!
Always disconnect power before replacing fuses to prevent electrical shock
Never work live unless you are authorized and supervised!
Working on energized circuits requires special training and authorization
Understanding Overloads
An overload is a moderate increase in current beyond the rated current value and exposes conductors and equipment to more current than their design allows.
A circuit becomes overloaded when the equipment connected to it draws more current than that for which the circuit is designed or rated. The heat produced by an overload often causes electrical insulation deterioration and failure. During an overload, the protective device must open before damage occurs.

Too Much Equipment

CSA Unit 12 Basic Electricity
Chapter 1
Power Supply for Gas Appliances
Most gas appliances are designed with some electrical components to aid in their operation. It is important for gas technicians and fitters to understand how power is supplied and accessed, as well as the various methods and devices used to ensure that electricity is distributed safely.
MK
by Mike Kapin
Purpose and Objectives
Safety First
Unit 1 Safety covers electrical safety and should be reviewed. Other important safety references are CSA Z460 and CSA Z462.
Learning Objectives
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
Describe an electrical service
Describe ground fault circuit interrupters (GFCI)
Describe electrical bonding to gas piping
Explain single-phase and three-phase power
Describe the types and ratings of fuses and breakers
Describe the types and gauges of wire
Key Terminology
Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
Ampacity
The amount of current a conductor is rated to safely handle
Bonding
Permanent joining of all non-current-carrying metal parts to ensure electrical continuity and establish a low-impedance path that can safely conduct any current likely to be imposed on it
Conductor
A material that allows electrical current to flow through it with relative ease
Electrolysis
Chemical breakdown of two metals in contact reacting with one another
Ground fault circuit interrupter
GFCI
A specially designed receptacle or distribution panel circuit breaker used to protect users of electrical appliances and equipment from electric shock
More Terminology
Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
Grounding
Connection of all exposed non-current-carrying metal parts to the earth that provides a direct path for unwanted current to the earth without causing harm to persons or equipment
Non-metallic-sheathed cable (dry)
NMD
For exposed wiring in dry or damp locations. For concealed wiring in dry or damp locations
Non-metallic-sheathed cable (wet)
NMW
For exposed wiring in dry locations and in Category 1 and 2 locations, where not exposed to mechanical damage; For exposed wiring in wet locations; For concealed wiring in dry locations and in Category 1 and 2 locations where not exposed to mechanical damage
Overcurrent device
Main circuit breaker or a pair of fuses that protect the line wires and transfer power to the two hot bus bars
Overload
Moderate increase in current beyond the rated current value
Electrical Service: Generation and Distribution
Power Generation
Almost all commercial electrical power on Earth is generated with a turbine, driven by wind, water, steam, or burning gas. The turbine drives a generator, thus transforming its mechanical energy into electrical energy through electromagnetic induction.
Three-Phase Generation
At the power station, an electrical generator converts mechanical power into a set of three alternating electric currents (AC), one from each coil (or winding) of the generator. Three-phase electric power is the most common method used by electrical grids worldwide to transfer power.
Transmission
At the power station, transformers change the voltage from generators to a higher level suitable for transmission in order to minimize losses over long distances.
Distribution
On arrival at a substation, the power is stepped down from transmission level voltage to distribution level voltage. Finally, upon arrival at the service location, the power is stepped down again to the required service voltage(s).
Electrical Grid Components
Generating Stations
Power plants that produce electrical power through various means such as hydroelectric, nuclear, coal, natural gas, wind, or solar.
Transmission Lines
High voltage lines that carry power from distant sources to demand centers, minimizing power loss over long distances.
Distribution Lines
Lower voltage lines that connect individual customers to the grid, delivering power at usable voltages for homes and businesses.
An electrical grid is an interconnected network for delivering electricity from producers to consumers. Central power stations became economically practical with the development of AC power transmission, using power transformers to transmit power at high voltage and with low loss.
Building Electrical Supply
From Street Grid to Building
The electrical supply to a building comes from the street grid and runs through wire conductors from a transformer located on a utility pole or in another location such as an underground vault.
Connection to Meter
The conductors (supply lines) connect to the building at a meter base installed on the exterior of the building or in a utility room.
Distribution Within Building
From the meter, power is distributed to various circuits through the main electrical panel, which contains circuit breakers or fuses to protect each circuit.
Understanding Phase in Electrical Power
Phase can be described as the difference in electrical degrees between two waveforms. Different types of electrical systems use different phase configurations.
Single-Phase Power
Single-phase electric power refers to the distribution of alternating current electric power using a system in which all the voltages of the supply vary in unison. If you were to graph the magnitude of current or voltage for AC single phase power, you would have a single-line sine wave.
Single-phase power comprises two independent voltages that are carried on two separate conductors. The two hot lines are called Line 1 and Line 2.
Three-Phase Power
The power generating station produces three different phases of AC power simultaneously. The three coils within the AC generator are 120 mechanical degrees apart. When the coils are rotating, three different voltages are produced with equal magnitude and frequency values.
This allows for higher motor starting torque and lower amperage (current draw) than is possible with a single-phase supply as it is a more constant and consistent power supply.
Single-Phase Power System
Transformer
A neutral wire connected to the midpoint of the secondary 240 V winding divides it to provide two voltages (120 V and 240 V) on a three-wire system.
Three-Wire System
The system consists of two hot lines (Line 1 and Line 2) and one neutral wire, which is grounded at the transformer and at the electrical panel.
Voltage Distribution
120 V supplies small appliances such as televisions, while 240 V supplies larger appliances such as electric ranges.
Residential Application
Most residential appliances operate on single-phase voltage, supplied by a transformer with primary and secondary windings.
Three-Phase Power System
Generation
The power generating station produces three different phases of AC power simultaneously. The three coils within the AC generator are 120 mechanical degrees apart.
When the coils are rotating, three different voltages are produced with equal magnitude and frequency values.
Advantages
Higher motor starting torque
Lower amperage (current draw)
More constant and consistent power supply
Generally more economical than equivalent single-phase or two-phase systems at the same voltage
Applications
Three-phase power supply is used to power large motors and other heavy loads. Three-phase, three- and four-wire systems are used for industrial and commercial applications.
Three-Phase System Configuration
Four-Wire System Components
Three hot line wires
A ground wire
A neutral may also be included, at times
Common Supplied Voltages
120/208 V
240/416 V
347/600 V
600 V
Color-Coding
Neutral (when present): White or natural grey
Phase A (phase wire A): Red
Phase B (phase wire B): Black
Phase C (phase wire C): Blue
Phase Sequence and Neutral Wire
Phase Sequence
The phase sequence, or the phase rotation, is the order in which the three voltages of a three-phase circuit flow one another. The phase sequence can be changed in two ways:
By reversing the direction of rotation of the three-phase generator
By interchanging the connections of any two of the three hot wires (This method may be necessary to change/correct the rotation of a three-phase motor at initial commissioning)
Neutral Wire Identification
The neutral wire (the identified circuit conductor) must have the same colour throughout the whole length of the circuit it services, for conductor sizes up to No. 2 AWG.
Identified circuit conductors larger than No. 2 AWG must be identified at both ends with white tape, unless the conductor is white.
Electrical Service Rating
100A
Minimum New Construction
The minimum requirement in most new residential construction
60A
Older Homes
Many older homes have this service rating
200A
Electric Heat
Homes heated by electricity require this service
The electrical service supplied to a building is measured in amps (amperes) or kilowatts, the unit of measurement for electrical current. The amperage rating of a service is the maximum total current draw of all electrical appliances in the building. As more appliances are added, the electrical service may need to be upgraded to a higher amperage rating. This often requires a new, larger capacity distribution panel and may require installation of larger capacity supply lines by the power supply authority.
Components of Electrical Service
Service Authority Responsibility
The local distribution power supply authority is responsible for the installation, maintenance, and servicing of supply conductors up to the meter base of the customer's building.
Underground supply lines enter the meter base through a protective conduit, eliminating the requirement for a service mast and its related hardware.
The components of a typical electrical service include the service entrance, meter base, main disconnect, and distribution panel. The configuration may vary between overhead and underground service connections.
Residential Electrical Distribution System
Electric Meter
The supply wires to a building first pass through an electric meter, which records the amount of electrical energy in kilowatt-hours consumed over a certain period.

Electrical Conductors and Wiring
This section explores the fundamentals of electrical conductors, wire types, insulation, and applications in electrical systems. Understanding these components is essential for proper electrical installation and maintenance in residential, commercial, and industrial settings.
Wire Conductors
Solid Wire Conductors
Solid copper wire is usually formed by drawing a soft copper rod through a series of doughnutshaped metal blocks called dies. Each successive die has a smaller diameter hole than the previous one. As the copper rod passes through the dies, it is reduced in diameter and becomes longer.
Stranded-Wire Conductors
A stranded-wire conductor consists of a group of wires that are twisted or braided together, often around a central core. A stranded wire acts as a single conductor, with nearly the same currentcarrying capacity as a single solid wire of the same gauge.
Stranded-wire conductors are usually No. 8 AWG and larger. The wires making up a stranded conductor normally have the same size. The size of the wires depends on the flexibility required - the smaller the diameter of the wire strands, the more flexible the conductor.
Conductor Size (Gauge)
American Wire Gauge (AWG) Standard
Wire conductors are sized according to the American Wire Gauge (AWG) standard.
Size Range
Sizes range from No. 44 AWG to No. 4/0 AWG (0000), as shown in the AWG wire conductor sizes table.
Inverse Relationship
The smaller the AWG number, the greater the diameter and cross-sectional area of the conductor.

Conductor Ampacity
Definition
Ampacity is the current-carrying capacity of electric conductors expressed in amperes.
Resistance Factors
The larger the AWG number of a conductor, the greater the electrical resistance per unit length.
The resistance of a conductor increases with temperature and, as resistance increases, the voltage drop increases.
Sizing Considerations
Long wiring runs may require the use of larger-gauge conductors in order to maintain required circuit voltage values and remain within ampacity limits - the same reason for properly sizing gas pipe.
Longer runs and larger pipe are required to maintain volume and pressure at the point of use within the allowable pressure drop.
Allowable Ampacities for Copper Conductors
The ampacity rating of wire conductor cables is specified in the CE Code. Ampacity rating depends on the type of cable, its insulation, and the maximum temperature to which the cable will be exposed.
AWG Size
60°C (Type TW)

90°C (Types R90, TW90, T90)
Conductor Insulation
Purpose
Prevent undesirable current flow and protect against electric shock
Common Materials
Rubber compounds, polyvinylchloride (PVC), and polyethylene plastic
Performance Requirements
Suitable voltage rating, temperature rating, environmental protection, and mechanical protection
Conductor Insulation Requirements
Voltage Rating
A conductor's voltage rating is printed on the insulation.
Electrical conductor insulation subjected to excessive voltage may break down and lose its insulating ability.
The ability of a conductor's insulation to resist breakdown due to voltage stress is its dielectric strength.
Temperature Rating
A conductor's temperature rating is printed on its outer surface.
If an electrical conductor is used in an application where it is exposed to excessive heat:
Its insulation may melt or burn, leaving the wire conductors bare
The life expectancy of the insulation may be greatly reduced
Stove wire, for example, has a high-temperature-resistant fibre wrapping over the top of its rubber or thermoplastic insulation to protect it from the heat of the appliance it services.
Environmental Considerations for Conductors
Moisture Resistance
The presence of moisture can reduce an insulation's dielectric strength
Chemical Resistance
Corrosive vapours can damage or destroy insulating materials
Mechanical Protection
Must provide adequate protection against physical damage
Fire Resistance
Some applications require special fire-resistant insulation
Cable Types for Different Locations
Cable
Location use
NMD (non-metallic dry)
For exposed wiring in dry or damp locations
For concealed wiring in dry or damp locations
NMW (non-metallic wet)
For exposed wiring in dry locations and in Category 1 and 2 locations, where not exposed to mechanical damage
For exposed wiring in wet locations
For concealed wiring in dry locations and in Category 1 and 2 locations where not exposed to mechanical damage
Unsheathed conductors
Run outdoors must be enclosed in a code-compliant raceway.
Mechanical Protection for Conductors
Identify Potential Hazards
The insulation of electrical conductors used in applications where they are exposed to possible physical damage must provide adequate protection.
Select Appropriate Protection
Some conductors have an outer layer of flexible metallic sheathing to protect the conductor and its insulation from damage.
Follow Code Requirements
For example, in order to prevent damage to conductors in locations where steel joists and studs are used as framing members, armoured cable (BX) is typically used however NMD cable is permitted when CE Code Rule 12-516, Protection for cable in concealed installations, is complied with.
Conductor Applications
Power Circuit Wiring
Electrical distribution conductors and cabling for residential, commercial, and industrial buildings
Fixture Wiring
Special type of wire approved for use within electrical equipment such as lighting fixtures
Low-Voltage Control Circuits
Circuits operating from 31V to 750V inclusive, or extra-low voltage circuits operating at 30V or less
Data Cabling
Provides sites telecommunication infrastructure, including twisted pair, coaxial, and fiber-optic
Power Circuit Wiring
Service Equipment
The service equipment, which uses the largest conductors, is the main power source for all other circuit wiring in the building.
Service equipment conductors usually require special mechanical protection, in accordance with Section 6 of the CE Code, and any local bulletins.
Branch Circuits
Branch circuits supply power to receptacle outlets, lighting, heater units, dryers, ranges, and motorized equipment.
Depending on the application and CE Code requirements, branch circuits use a variety of conductor types, including:
Non-metallic sheathed cable
Armoured cable
Mineral-insulated cable
Thermoplastic and rubber-coated cable
Conductors in conduit
Fixture Wiring
Definition
Fixture wire is a special type of wire approved for use within electrical equipment such as lighting fixtures. It is usually a stranded, flexible conductor with high-temperature rated insulation.
Usage
This wire, also known as equipment wire, is used to connect internal fixtures to branch circuit conductors.
Characteristics
Typically stranded for flexibility
High temperature rating for use in lighting fixtures
Specialized insulation for specific applications
Low Voltage Control Circuits
1
Low Voltage Circuits
The CE Code defines low voltage circuits as those operating from 31V to 750V inclusive
Motor Control Circuits
Some motor control circuits operate at 600V
Extra-Low Voltage Circuits
Operate at 30V or less
Residential Applications
Thermostat, gas valve, and zone valve control circuits
Data Cabling
Data cables and associated hardware provide sites telecommunication infrastructure. Modern gas equipment is often equipped with network interface devices (NID) to enable them to connect to local area networks (LAN).
Twisted Pair
Often used in data networks for short and medium length connections because of its relatively lower costs compared to optical fibre and coaxial cable.
Coaxial
Used for longer runs and applications requiring greater bandwidth and noise immunity.
Fibre-Optic
Used for high-speed, long-distance data transmission with complete electrical isolation.
Twisted Pair Cabling
Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP)
The most common cable used in computer networking as the twisting of pair of conductors in the cable provide shielding from electromagnetic interference.
Shielded Twisted Pair (STP)
Additional shielding from high-frequency signals applied to individual pairs with foil and/or braided metal fibre.
Screened Twisted Pair (ScTP)
Shield applied to a collection of pairs for protection against electromagnetic interference in high-noise environments.
Conductor Colour Codes
The wires of electrical conductors must be marked for easy identification so they can be correctly connected in circuits. There are several different methods used to differentiate wiring.
Common Marking Methods
The insulation of each wire is a different colour
The insulation of each conductor may have an attached label marker or wire number (larger cables have a coloured strip)
Standard Colour Codes
Colour
Use
White or grey
Only for insulated, neutral conductors or identified conductors
Green
Only for insulated grounding or bonding conductors
Red, black, and blue
Typically identifies live (ungrounded) conductors
Non-metallic Sheathed Cable (NMSC and NMD)
Description
Non-metallic sheathed cable usually has PVC or polyethylene plastic insulation, which also serves as the outer covering of the cable. This type of cable is most commonly used for wiring branch circuits.
Cautions
The non-metallic covering of electric cables can burn and may transmit fire when ignited
Burning non-metallic coverings may emit highly toxic gases that generate dense smoke
Acidic gas emissions may corrode metals in the vicinity of the cable

3. Measuring and test instruments 
Overview 
Purpose 
A gas technician/fitter must be capable of solving problems on a regular basis. In many cases, 
these problems will be electrical ones. Solving these problems requires a thorough knowledge of 
the system and the tools required to determine where the problems lie. This means that the gas 
technician/fitter must be familiar with the various types of electrical measuring and test devices, 
as well as how and where they are applied. 
When working with electrical testing equipment, gas technicians/fitters must protect themselves 
from electrical hazards. Reviewing Unit 1 Safety is recommended. 
For information on the basic selection, use, and maintenance of common electrical testing and 
measuring instruments, refer to Unit 5 Introduction to electricity, Chapter 7. Electrical measuring 
instruments. 
Objectives 
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to: 
describe the types and applications of measuring and test instruments; and 
• describe the safe operation and connection of measuring and test instruments. 
Terminology 
Tenn 
Abbreviation Definition 
(Symbol) 
Digital multimeter 
DMM 
Digital electronic measuring instrument that 
combines several functions in one unit 
Volt-0hm-milliammeter

Electronic measuring instrument that combines 
several functions in one unit 
Types and applications of measuring and test 
instruments 
Electrical measuring and test instruments include various types of meters. recorders, and 
analyzers. These instruments may be analogue or digital-type units (Figure 3-1 ). 
Analogue instruments indicate measured values with a scale and pointer display. The pointer's 
movement is directly and continuously related to the measured quantity. 
Digital instruments interpret the measured quantity electronically in discrete numerical data 
(digits). They have a numerical display that is formed by light-€mitting diodes (LEDs) or liquid 
crystal displays (LCDs).
Figure 3-1 
Digital and analog multimeters

We will focus on the digital multimeter (DMM) as it is the most common type in use today. 
As discussed in Unit 2 Fasteners, tools, and testing instruments and in Unit 5 Introduction to 
electricity, a digital multimeter (DMM) combines the functions of a voltmeter, an ammeter, and an 
ohmmeter. Digital multimeters also have advanced features that vary among DMM models from 
different manufacturers.

The function dial normally has positions that will allow a technician to measure AC volts, DC 
volts, DC amps, and resistance. In addition, some DMMs have function switch positions that will
allow a technician to measure AC amps and to test diodes and capacitors. Some DMMs require 
manual selling of ranges, and others have an autoranging feature. 
Voltage functions 
Electrical potential and voltage are measured in volts Mor millivolts (mV). 
The voltage function measures the difference in electric potential between two points in a circuit. 
There are two types of voltage sources, AC voltage and DC voltage. The current flow caused by 
an AC voltage source changes in both magnitude and direction at regular intervals. The current 
flow caused by a DC voltage source does not change direction. The AC voltage function is 
commonly used to test and troubleshoot receptacles, gas appliance power supply, transformers, 
and other AC control circuits. A DMM set for the DC voltage function can be used to test battery 
banks and to troubleshoot DC motors, DC generators and other DC circuits 
Millivolt function 
Some DMM may have a dedicated DC millivolt setting that is more accurate than the DC 
autorange voltage function. This function is useful for testing very low millivolt systems such as 
thermocouples. 
Ammeter function 
Electric current flow is measured in amperes (A), milliamperes (mA), or microamperes (µA). The 
word •ampere• is commonly shortened to •amp". So, for example, a milliampere would be called 
a milliamp. The DMM has a setting for AC and DC current. Most DMMs can measure DC or AC 
currents from the micro-amp range to a maximum of 10 amps. For higher amperage circuits, a 
clamp-on ammeter is recommended. 
Clamp-on ammeter 
Clamp-on ammeters (Figure 3-3) are designed to eliminate the need to interrupt circuit operation 
to measure current in the circuit. Clamp-0n meters are generally used to measure alternating 
current or direct current only, but some digital clamp-on meters will measure ac and de, as well as 
voltage and resistance. 
A clamp-on ammeter has the following advantages: 
It causes minimal circuit loading because it is not connected in series with the load. 
It does not require the use of external shunts, as some in-line ammeters do. 
It is generally more rugged than an in-line ammeter.
Figure 3-3 
Clamp meter 
Courtesy of The Industry Training Authority 
Ohmmeter function 
Any circuit with an ability to conduct some electrical current is said to have electrical continuity. 
The amount of resistance there is to current flow is measured in ohms (Q) or kilohms (kO). 
The ohmmeter function can be used to measure both resistance and continuity in a circuit. 
An ohmmeter function is powered by a small battery that causes current flow through the tested 
circuit's resistance, therefore a DMM set for ohms must not be used on an energized circuit. A 
DMM set for ohms can be used to test the continuity of a fuse or a switch. The resistance of an 
open switch or faulty fuse would indicate OL (infinity) on the display, and a closed switch or good 
fuse would indicate a very small resistance value on the display. 
Specialized meters 
In addition to the basic meters, gas technicians/fitters may often be required to use other 
instruments such as: 
• megohmmeters (meggers) -for measuring insulation resistance; and 
• capacitor analyzers -
for measuring actual capacitance values. 
Megohmmeter 
An Insulation resistance tester also called a megohmmeter (Figure 3-4) is used for measuring the 
resistance of electrical insulation in, for example, motor and transformer windings. It measures 
values in the 20 kilohm to 2000 megohm range. 
The component or apparatus being tested is disconnected from the circuit and the megohmmeter 
leads connected (one to the frame and one to the windings). The instrument applies a de voltage 
to the component, and the insulation value is read at 30 seconds and again at 1 minute after

Capacitor analyzer 
Unlike an ohmmeter, which only indicates if a capacitor has capacitance, a capacitor analyzer 
can test actual capacitance. Its principal function is the detection of current leakage that would 
normally only be obvious during circuit operation. It can also detect if a capacitor is open or 
shorted-out. 
Capacitor testers come in many different types and designs. Stand-alone testers may have a 
digital read-out or bar graph, while some just have LED indicators. Frequently, digital multimeters 
now have the ability to test most capacitors used with gas-fired equipment.

instruments 
A gas technician/fitter must be able to identify various electrical test and measuring instruments,

prior to use. It you are unsure of how to use them, contact your supervisor for clarification. 
Important: 
Safety is the single most important concern when working on electrical equipment. 
All workers must be trained to use the equipment in analyzing or troubleshooting problems with

Always wear the required personal protective equipment.

4. Circuits and hardware 
Overview 
Purpose 
Knowing how and from where electricity is supplied helps the gas technician/fitter install and 
maintain gas equipment. Whether the source is an electrical panel, a junction box, or a 
transformer, a basic knowledge of the relevant hardware and circuitry is important. 
It should be noted that electricians are required to perform electrical work under a permit in all 
jurisdictions in Canada. Gas technicians/fitters should check with the local electrical authority 
having jurisdiction (AHJ) for requirements. Gas and mechanical trades are permitted to perform 
elementary electrical work in some Canadian jurisdictions. 
Objectives 
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to: 
describe electrical panels and transformers; 
describe electrical hardware; and 
explain wiring diagrams.

Residential electrical service 
The electrical service coming into a residential distribution panel is 240 volts M, single-phase, 60 
hertz (240/1/60). The service conductors consist of: 
-

There is also a separate grounding conductor that connects the neutral and the metal distribution 
panel to a grounding electrode. The neutral is permitted to be grounded only once.

The 120 V supply is connected to the primary winding terminals of the transformer and the 
appliance control circuit connected to the 24 V secondary winding terminals. The 120 V 
alternating current flow through the primary winding induces a 24 V current in the secondary 
winding to power the appliance control circuit. 
It is important to make sure transformers are bonded by a bonding conductor to the cabinet bond. 
This is critical for troubleshooting. 
T ransfonner ratings 
Manufacturers always specify the voltage rating of a transformer's primary and secondary 
windings. Secondary winding rated voltages are specified for full-load conditions with the rated 
primary voltage.
Operating a transformer's primary at higher than rated voltage may cause the transformer to 
overheat, damaging its insulation. Operating the primary at lower than rated voltage does no 
harm, but secondary voltages will be less than rated values. 
Current ratings are generally specified for secondary windings only. If the secondary current 
rating is not exceeded, the primary current capacity cannot be exceeded. 
Transformer ratings are based on the amount of power the secondary winding can handle. 
Transformer power ratings can be specified in two ways: 
by the volt-ampere (YA) rating; and 
-
by the power rating in watts. 
The volt-ampere rating of a transformer is the product of the voltage and amperage (YA = V x A). 
A power rating specified in watts is understood to be the power that a transformer can deliver to a 
resistive load. The power rating in watts is the product of the current rating and the voltage rating 
of the secondary winding (P = E x I). 
Some transformers are fused internally. If there is no indication of fusing, it is good practice to 
include fusing when replacing or installing new transformers. New equipment usually has the 
transformer integral to the main circuit board, which may be equipped with a fuse. 
Transformers are indicated on electrical diagrams in two ways, as shown in Figure 4-3.

In order to property install and service gas appliances and equipment, gas technicians/fitters 
must be able to identify and use the following types of electrical hardware: 
connection devices; 
switches, relays, and contactors; 
boxes;

conduit or raceways.
Connection devices 
The CE Code requires that all connections be made only in outlet or junction boxes. The 
electrical connections used for the installation of gas appliances and equipment fall into two basic 
groups: 
solderless terminals and insulators; and 
• soldered connections. 
Solderless tenninals and insulators 
Solderless terminals and insulators include crimp-on-type and insulated cap-type connectors. 
Crimp-on connectors 
Crimp-on connectors are used to secure twisted and untwisted wire joints. This type of connector 
can be a slip-on metal cap for pig-tail joints, or a metal sleeve for splicing two straight wires. The 
two-part connector (Figure 4-4) has a conductor retaining sleeve that is compressed by using 
special crimping pliers and an insulated screw cap into which the crimped retainer is inserted. 
Figure 4-4 
Crimp-on connector and pliers 
Courtesy of Camosun College, BC Campus Open Textbook, licenced under CC BY 
Insulated cap connectors 
There are several types of insulated-cap connectors. Also known as wire nut connectors or 
marrettes by the manufacturer Marr. This type of connector is used for pig-tail joints of two or 
more conductors. 
The two most common insulated-cap connectors are the twist-on type and the set-screw type 
(Figure 4-5). They are both available in several colour coded sizes to accommodate a wide range 
of conductors. 
The set-screw connectors consist of a brass connector body and an insulated cap. The twisted 
conductors are slid into the brass connector body and secured with the hold-down screw before 
the plastic insulating cap is screwed in place. 
Twist-on connectors have a cone-shaped coiled wire insert that grips the twisted conductors to 
ensure good electrical contact. When the connector is twisted onto the stripped end of the wires, 
the wire is drawn and squeezed into the metal insert.
Figure 4-5 
Insulated cap connectors
