Follow the instructions that are included with each type of connector to ensure the connector is 
correctly joining the wire. 
It is good practice to check these connectors periodically to tighten them if required since 
expansion and contraction loosen them over time. 
Modular connectors 
Modular connectors were originally designed for use in telephone wiring but have since been 
used for many other purposes. Many applications that originally used a bulkier, more expensive 
connector have converted to modular connectors. Probably the best-known applications of 
modular connectors are for telephone and Ethernet.

5. Millivolt systems 
Overview 
Purpose 
Many gas-fired appliances are considered self-contained or self-powered. It is very common to 
encounter appliances equipped with devices that generate electricity and that have components 
that operate on direct current millivolt. This voltage is generated using heat from the gas flame 
and is used to operate minor control and safety circuits and extended systems, especially in off-
grid applications. 
The gas technician/fitter must have complete knowledge of how this voltage is generated as well 
as the amount of voltage that is generated. The gas technician/fitter must also know how this 
voltage is distributed through the circuit and the test procedures used to isolate problems when 
September 2020

Basic electricity for gas-fired equipment 
they arise. The electrical principles remain the same, but millivolt systems have very specific 
applications and restrictions. 
Objectives 
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to: 
• explain the generation of de millivolt systems; 
• explain the procedure used to test control circuits; and 
• describe millivolt thermostats. 
Terminology

generate more voltage than a single

Thermopile

Generation of small-value DC voltages 
Unlike alternating current (AC), direct current flows in one direction only. Direct current (DC) is 
used in many different applications in North America. 
It is normally used to power electronic devices, control relays on most building automation 
systems, small appliances, automotive electrical systems, and, recently, solar panels. DC is often 
supplied by some form of battery or power supply converter. However, other means, such as 
heating a bimetallic device called a thermocouple, can generate small de voltages. 
Thermocouple 
A simple thermocouple consists of two wires, made of dissimilar (different) metals joined together 
at one end. The end at which they are joined is called the hot junction, while the opposite end is 
the cold junction. 
When sufficient heat is applied to the hot junction of a thermocouple, a small voltage is generated 
at the cold junction, causing a positive-to-negative direct current flow. If the cold junction is 
heated, current will flow in the opposite direction (negative-to-positive). The voltage generated is 
so small that it is measured in millivolts (mV). A millivolt is 1/1000 of a volt. Thermocouples 
generate voltages in the 0-30 mV range. 
Some thermocouples consist of a wire located in the centre of a small, circular metal tube. The 
tube and wire, which are made of dissimilar (different) metals, are joined at one end to form the 
hot junction (the opposite end is the cold junction). 
112 
September 2020
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 12 
Basic electricity for gas-fired equipment 
'Thertnocouple application 
Thermocouples are used as a flame detection device or flame safeguard on appliances that have 
constant pilots. They are also used on appliances with manual reset controls. The thermocouple 
shown in Figure 5-1 is an integral part of a combustion safety circuit for a gas furnace. The 
thermocouple assembly is attached with a threaded male fitting, as shown in Figure 5-1. 
When the pilot burner heats the hot junction, the thermocouple generates a voltage to power the 
electromagnet coil in the safety shut-off valve or safety switch. As long as the pilot remains lit, the 
spring-loaded solenoid shut-off valve or safety switch will remain open to allow the flow of gas to 
the main and pilot burners. The pilot stays on constantly, but the main valve still requires a 
separate control circuit and voltage to operate (i.e., a 24 V supply and thermostat). If the pilot light 
goes out, the thermocouple will cool down, and the resulting drop in voltage will be unable to 
energize the electromagnetic coil. The spring-loaded safety switch or shut off valve will then shut 
off the flow of gas. 
Most thermocouples supply only a small current in milliamps that is just enough to energize a 
very small electromagnetic solenoid.

must cool down and de-energize the safety shut-off valve or safety switch within 90 seconds. 
For this reason, thermocouples are only approved for use with gas appliances with inputs up to

However, there is an exception to this rule. A single thermocouple may be used to supervise 
inputs of natural gas appliances with inputs of up to 1 000 000 Btu/h (300 kW) if they have 
unrestricted vertical flue passes. Appliances with a specific gravity greater than air (such as 
propane) shall have a maximum flame response time of 20 seconds. These appliances will be 
equipped with fast response thermocouples (Figure 5-2). As many of these appliances, such as

Fast response thermocouple 
Hot junction 
The thermocouple only generates a voltage if the temperature difference between the hot and 
cold junctions is at least 400°F (204 °C). 
The greater the temperature difference, the greater the voltage generated. For this reason, it is 
important that the pilot flame heat only the first 0.375 to 0.5 inch (10 mm to 13 mm) of the hot 
junction -
no other part of the thermocouple should be heated. 
Cold junction 
One of the ends of the cold junction is connected to the copper outer sleeve of the thermocouple, 
creating one of the conductors of the supply circuit. While the other lead from the cold junction is 
connected to an insulated wire enclosed in the copper sleeve, which terminates at a coaxial 
connection that is connected to the safety switch or safety shut-off valve. 
Powerpile generator 
A powerpile, also known as a thermopile, consists of multiple thermocouples joined together at 
one end and connected in series to generate more voltage than a single thermocouple (Figure 5-
3). The total voltage generated by a thermopile is the sum of the voltages generated by each 
thermocouple it contains. 
Most modern thermopiles consist of 10 to 30 thermocouples connected in series. 
Powerpile output ranges from 250 to 750 mV, which allows the powerpile to power an appliance's 
combustion safety circuit and its control circuit. 
Powerpile generators (Figure 5-4) are used on appliances with automatic-type controls. 
Pilot/powerpile generators, as they are called, generate electrical direct current power from the 
flame of a single pilot source. This makes the appliance self-sufficient for stand-alone 
applications.

Two types of powerpile are shown in Figure 5-4: 
• coaxial (on the left); and 
• two wire (on the right). 
A coaxial powerpile looks like a thermocouple; however, its hot junction and contact end are 
larger. A two-wire powerpile has two cold junction leads that are covered with protective armour. 
Some have the same connecting nut as a thermocouple.

Nameplate information 
Electric motors have nameplates that provide the gas technician/fitter with valuable information 
for selecting and installing a motor. 
Note: Do not remove or deface nameplates. 
Typical nameplate information 
Figure 6-1 shows a typical motor nameplate for a single-phase induction motor. The nameplate 
gives the following information: 
• Thermal protection describes the motors over temperature protection. A large percentage of 
fractional horsepower motors are provided with built-in thermal protection. Individual 
manufacturers may use their own systems to mark the kinds of protection and the type of 
thermal protector. 
• Type and application indicate a split-phase, fan, and blower motor. Motors fall into a number of 
different types of classifications, as shown in Table 6-1, which also indicates types of motors 
and their applications. 
• Model number (MOD.) is set by the manufacturer. 
• Horsepower of motor (HP) is rated as 1 /3 (a fractional horsepower motor). 
• Speed of motor (RPM) at full-load speed is 1725 rev/min. 
• Voltage (V) operates on 115 V (sometimes two voltage figures are given, such as 115/230; in 
this case, the motor is intended for use on either a 115 V or 230 V circuit). 
• full-load amperage (F.L.A), also known as RLA rated-load amperage, (of 5.5 amps) refers to 
the approximate current drawn by the motor when developing rated horsepower on a circuit of 
the voltage and frequency specified on the nameplate. 
• Frame sizes (FR.) are classified by their diameter. Sizes are used to obtain frame dimensions 
such as the overall length and diameter of the motor and distances between mounting bolts. 
They also indicate shaft length, diameter, and height. 
• Frequency is designed to operate on a 60 Hz AC voltage. 
• PH specifies the phases of the motor. A single-phase motor is indicated with a 1. 
• LRA or the locked rotor amperage is used to determine the amount of locked rotor current, 
which is the amount of current the motor will draw at the moment of starting. Standard letter 
codes are also used to classify motors by the ratio of locked rotor kVA per horsepower. The

example nameplate in Figure 6-1 a kVA code letter "N" which has an approximate mid-range 
kVA/HP of 12. When calculated at 115 volts the LRA would be approximately 35 amps. 
• INS.CL indicates a B class of insulation (130 °C) is the thermal breakdown resistance 
temperature of the windings. 
• MAX AMB or maximum ambient temperature (of 40 °C) indicates the temperature at which the 
motor is capable of operating in without overheating the windings. 
• Continuous duty (C DUTY) designation means the motor can run continuously without 
needing to be cooled down, such as an intermittently rated motor would require. 
• S.F or Service factor (of 1.35) is the amount of excess short-term current (load) a motor is 
able to handle for a short time. 
• Bearings (BRG.) for fractional and sub fractional horsepower motors normally use sleeve 
bearings or ball bearings. 
• Motor reference (MTR REF) is part of the manufacturer's identification of the electrical and 
mechanical features of the motor. 
• Date code indicates when the motor was manufactured.

Additional nameplate information 
A variety of additional information may appear on the nameplate. This may include instructions 
for connecting the motor to a source of supply, reversing the direction of rotation, lubricating the 
motor, or operating it safely. 
Construction and operation of electric motors 
All electric motors have a similar basic structure. They have two main parts (Figure 6-2): 
• stator ( or frame); and 
• rotor. 
September 2020 
141
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 12 
Basic electricity for gas-fired equipment 
Figure 6-2 
Stator and rotor of an electric motor 
Stator 
Rotor 
Stator 
The stator is stationary, consisting of two or more electromagnets and their windings. It is usually 
cylindrical in shape, with the field poles facing and projecting their magnetic fields into the centre 
space of the cylinder. The windings are connected to a source of AC, which causes the poles to 
change polarity in step with the changing direction of the AC. 
Rotor 
The rotor is mounted on a rotating shaft in the centre of the stator. It has a laminated iron core 
containing aluminum (sometimes copper) rods or bars along its outer surface. The rods or bars 
are almost parallel to the rotor shaft and serve as the conductors through which current flows. 
(Note that the rotors of most induction motors do not contain windings.) 
At the ends of the rotor are rings connecting the rods or bars together, completing the current 
paths. The bars and rings look like a squirrel cage. The direction of current flow in some bars will 
be opposite of that in others. As the rotor turns, the bars swing across magnetic fields created by 
the stator poles, inducing current in them (Figure 6-3). 
Figure 6-4 shows how the current in each of the rotor's copper rod sets up a magnetic field 
around the wire that interacts with the magnetic field created by the stator poles. The direction of 
current flow in the conductor is indicated by: 
• a cross sign (x) for current away from you (or the tail feathers of an arrow); and 
• a dot (•)for current towards you (the head of an arrow).

The magnetic lines of force set up by the current in the conductor will be in opposite directions 
above and below the conductor. This magnetic field interacts with the magnetic field of the stator 
poles. Since "like" magnetic lines repel each other, and "unlike" fields attract each other, the rotor 
starts to turn inside the stator. 
Figure 6-5 shows the forces produced by opposite currents in bars on both sides of the rotor, 
causing the torque that makes the rotor rotate. The polarity changes when AC current is applied 
to the bars, constantly changing the attraction and repulsion forces causing a continuous rotation 
or spinning motion.

The frequency of the current change determines the motor speed. Typical AC power is supplied 
at 60 hertz (Hz or cycles per second), so the rotor of a motor with two poles would turn 60 times 
every second, or 3600 revolutions per minute (RPM). The more poles a motor has, the slower the 
motor will turn. 
You can use the following formula to determine the synchronous speed (without load) of motors 
in RPM: 
Frequency x 120

This calculation would give theoretical motor speed. Internal motor friction and the mechanisms 
or drives to which the motor is connected would affect the actual speed, adding a certain amount 
of resistance to rotation. The difference between the motor-calculated speed and the actual 
speed is referred to as motor slip. Excessive motor slip can indicate improper motor lubrication, 
defective motor bearings, poorly adjusted belts (too tight), or an improperly selected motor for the 
desired application (overload).

Part B: Short Answer (Sample Answers)
Series vs. Parallel Circuits: In a series circuit, current flows through each component one after the other; if one fails, the whole circuit stops. In a parallel circuit, components are connected across the same voltage source and can operate independently; failure of one doesn't affect others. In gas-fired equipment, parallel circuits allow independent control of components like fans and ignitors.
Safety Switches: These are fail-safe mechanisms that shut off power or gas flow when unsafe conditions are detected (e.g., high temperature, blocked flue, or open blower door). They prevent system damage and hazards like fires or explosions.
Flame Sensor: Detects the presence of a flame using flame rectification (the ability of flame to conduct current). Dirt, oxidation, or poor grounding can cause malfunction. Cleaning or replacing the sensor typically resolves issues.
Common Problems:
Loose connections: Cause intermittent operation; fixed by inspecting and tightening terminals.
Blown fuse: Stops the control circuit; diagnosed via multimeter and replaced.
Faulty thermostat: Misreads temperature; tested by bypassing or substituting.

Total current draw = 0.5A + 0.25A = 0.75A

Learning Outcome:
Upon completion of this shop project, you will understand the wiring connections, safety controls, and sequence of operation for a basic millivolt system and SIT 820 NOVA valve.
Instructions:
Using the simulation board and diagrams below, you will wire up a millivolt gas valve control system to take readings and answer the following questions. The millivolt system and components may be checked with a voltmeter having a range of 0 – 1000 mV.
Note: Each step must be signed off by the instructor before proceeding to the next question. Skipped sign offs will result in lost marks (5 per). Any damage to the systems components due to negligence or horseplay will result in a mark of zero for the practical.
Follow all shop safety rules.
Neatly, with components labeled, convert the below wiring diagram into a ladder diagram in the space provided (8 marks). Then wire your simulation board using the schematic you created. Verify with the instructor when completed. (4 marks)
Sign off: ____________________
Using the reference table and valve layout below, conduct each of the following measurements to the appropriate terminals and verify your readings.
Have the thermostat contacts open and pilostat knob turned to the off position. Coil resistance should be around 2.25 ohms. If not, replace the valve.
The system resistance from the remote switch or thermostat and lead wires should not exceed 1.7 ohms. If greater, reduce the resistance by reducing the thermostat run length, use a larger gauge wire, or replace the thermostat.
With the pilostat knob turned to “Pilot” and the thermostat open, push down the pilot valve button and ignite the pilot flame with the piezo ignitor. There should be a minimum of 325 mV. If not, inspect the position of the thermopile in the flame and the cleanliness of thermopile. If both are adequate, replace the thermopile.
With the pilostat knob left in the “Pilot” position and pilot still burning, close the thermostat contacts. The thermopile should provide at least 100 mV. If not, replace the thermopile. If the input is at least 100 mV, the valve operator will make an audible click inside the valve when it engages. If the valve does not make a sound, replace it.

Electrical Practical 2 – Worksheet
Learning Outcome:
Upon completion of this shop project, you will better understand how to follow and wire up a schematic diagram, understand the flow of electricity, and understand the use of the components associated with the lab.
Instructions:
Make sure your schematic/ladder diagram, sequence of operation and wiring diagram has been completed and collected by the instructor.
Wire up your project board with the schematic given on the final page. In addition:
Ensure components are secured on the workstation.
All connections made with the circuit de-energised.
It should be wired neatly.
6” of wire inside every box.
All 120V connections are made within the electrical boxes.
Wires stripped correctly (no scoring or weakening).
Wires wrapped clockwise around light holder terminals and inside marrettes.
Wires secure (tug test).
Safety glasses must be worn during testing and operation of the boards.
Ensure proper test meters are selected.
Plug leads into correct meter outlets for ohms, volts, and amperage.
Correctly select the applicable range on meter selector switch.
Apply meter use correctly (If unsure ask!!)
Ohmmeter is used with circuit de-energised.
Stay clear of operating fans.
Once your board project has been fully wired, the instructor has approved the wiring and signed off, you may supply power to the board.
Sign off: _______________
Note: Each step must be signed off by the instructor before proceeding to the next question. Skipped sign offs will result in lost marks (5 per). Any damage to the systems components due to negligence or horseplay will result in a mark of zero for the practical.
Follow all shop safety rules.
With your Disconnect switch energized, answer the following questions:
What is the voltage across the on/off switch when it is open? _______________
What is the voltage across the on/off switch when it is closed? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the primary side of the transformer? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the secondary side of the transformer? ______________
What is the voltage drop across the Relay Coil with no call for heat? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the relay coil when energized? _______________
What is the amperage draw of the relay coil when energized? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the relay contact associated with the inducer fan when the inducer fan is operating? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the relay contact associated with the inducer fan when the inducer fan is not operating? _______________
What is the amperage draw of the inducer fan when energized? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the relay contact associated with the light bulb when the light bulb is operating? _______________
What is the voltage drop across the relay contact associated with the light bulb when the light bulb is not operating? _______________
What is the amperage draw of the light bulb when energized? _______________
What is the voltage across the high limit of the Fan/Limit when the switch is closed? _______________
What is the voltage across the high limit of the Fan/Limit when the switch is open? _______________
What is the voltage across the fan switch of the Fan/Limit when the fan is off? _______________
What is the voltage across the fan switch of the Fan/Limit when the fan is operating? _______________
What is the amperage draw of the blower fan when operating? _______________
What is the voltage across the thermostat when it is calling for heat? _______________
What is the voltage across the thermostat when not calling for heat? _______________
What is (or should) the thermostat anticipator setting (be)? _______________
What is the voltage across the vent limit when there is a call for heat? _______________
What would the voltage be across a functional fuse? _______________
What would the voltage be across a blown fuse? _______________
Sign off: _______________
****Remember to de-energize the circuit for any resistance checks****
What is the resistance reading across the primary side of the transformer? ______________
What is the resistance reading across the secondary side of the transformer? ____________
What is the resistance reading across the fan? _______________
What is the resistance of the relay coil? _______________
What is the resistance of the NO relay contact? _______________
What is the resistance of the NC relay contact? _______________
What is the resistance of the lightbulb? _______________
What is the VA rating of the transformer? _______________
What does the VA rating mean? _________________________________________________
______________________________________________________________________________
What is the size of transformer required for your project?
(Secondary voltage X secondary amperage X 125%) _________________________________
What size transformer would be used for heat only systems?  40 VA or 20 VA
What size transformer would be used for heat/ cool systems?  40 VA or 20 VA
Sign off: _______________
What would be an acceptable “Fan ON” temperature setting for a Fan/Limit control on a furnace? _______________
What is the “Fan ON” temperature setting of the Fan/Limit control on your project? _____________
What would be an acceptable “Fan OFF” temperature setting for a Fan/Limit control on a furnace? _______________
What is the “Fan OFF” temperature setting of the Fan/Limit control on your project? _______________
What would be an acceptable “HIGH LIMIT” temperature setting for a Fan/Limit control on a furnace? _______________
What is the “HIGH LIMIT” temperature setting of the Fan/Limit control on your project? _______________
Explain the function on the white push/pull button associated with your fan/limit control:
___________________________________________________________________________
At what temperature did the Fan/Limit control turn on the blower fan on your project? _______________
At what temperature did the Fan/Limit control turn off the blower fan after the call for heat was satisfied? _______________
Explain how to test the high limit: _______________________________________________
___________________________________________________________________________
___________________________________________________________________________
Operate your system with the fan disconnected. Does the high limit shut down the system? (Note: You may also have to change the limit setting down to achieve this) ______________
Once completed, do not dismantle your board! Ask the instructor to verify the board for marking. (30 marks)
Sign off: _______________
